column40: Layher (1993) reports that he believes that velocities corresponding to 'difficulty holding' could be maintained for 'some time'; and fish would assuredly be able to traverse the short distances involved in passing through culverts.

column37: Used mild electric shock to induce burst swimming and measured speeds maintained for a range of times (1 to 20 seconds.
column40: Eight goldfish were tested at 6 arbitrarily chosen times (1; 2.5; 3; 5; 10; 15; 20).  Swim speed was recorded for each test time.

Bell (1991) cite Fry and Hart (1948) that averaged many measurements sustained for 20 to 25 minutes.  The mean weight of the fish tested was 4.37 grams at 25 degrees C. Fish of this size swam an average of 50.8 cm/s.

Bell 1991 cites Jones et al. 1974 as the data source and states that 'Alaska data used to extend swimming speed to darting level'; it is not clear how Alaska data were used to estimate burst swimming speeds.
Hunter and Mayor used Jones et al. 1974 as the data source and used the group average ''c'' coefficient.
Pooled mean and standard errors were calculated from data - given no significant differences were found.  Pooled mean and variance see Zarr (1984) pages 132 and 125 respectively.

Bell 1991 cites Jones et al. 1974 as the data source and states that 'Alaska data used to extend swimming speed to darting level'; it is not clear how Alaska data was used to estimate burst swimming speeds.
Length-velocity correlation coefficient was not significant; caution should be used when using the regression equation.
Hunter and Mayor 1986 used an assumed beta (not clear how it was derived). Length-velocity correlation coefficient was not significant; caution should be used when using the regression equation.
The relationship between swim speed and fish length was significant.  The formula is valid for length range and time to exhaustion reported. The formula was converted from fish length in mm to m.
The formula given in the paper did not match the discussion or the graph.  The sign before the last set of numbers was changed (i.e. from ...+ 0.00061 (delta V)^2 to …- 0.00061 (delta V)^2.

column37: Fixed velocity test recorded time to fatigue between 72 and 12000 sec
Fish swam up chute of various velocities in tests of weir designs
column40: Speeds were observed by Powers and Orsborn (1985) fish swimming up a chute.  Swim speed is the center of the range observed by Powers and Orsborn (1985).
Because the time increment is very short 300 s (5 minutes) these speeds will be on the upper end of the prolonged speeds for juveniles of this species.

column37: Swim speed estimated from a ratio of burst and prolonged based data from sockeye salmon
column40: This prolonged speed was derived by multiplying the ratio of prolonged/burst speed from sockeye salmon (10.2 fps/20.6 fps = 0.495) by the burst speed of chum salmon (0.495*10.6 fps = 5.2fps or 150 cm/s).
Chum are poor leapers and appear to need optimum hydraulic conditions to make successful leaps. Speed should not be interpreted as range of burst speeds of which chum are capable.
Chum are poor leapers and appear to need optimum hydraulic conditions to make successful leaps.

Jones et al. 1974 tested wild and hatchery and found wild fish had a swim speed range and standard error that were twice those of hatchery fish.  Concluded variability in wild fish inherent.

column37: Data from different tests: fish swum through a fishway increasing velocity and electric shock to induce bursts.
column40: The data for this velocity formula includes both European rainbow and steelhead from Washington (USA).  Data from differing methods were combined reducing the confidence the user should have in this formula.
Bell (1991) cites several unpublished reports from the 1950s that were unavailable.  The methods used to develop these swim speeds is unknown.
Bell (1991) cites several unpublished reports from the 1950s that were unavailable.  The methods used to develop these swim speeds is unknown.

Jones et al. (1974) tested hatchery and wild steelhead to determine whether the extreme swim speed variability was due to handling stress or was inherent in wild populations - they concluded the variability was inherent in wild populations.
